qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I mainly use my phone for calling my supervisor, residents, and family members. Sometimes residents call me if the gate is locked or if a delivery has come. I also use WhatsApp to receive duty messages and voice calls. At night, I watch YouTube videos for time pass.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, sometimes I share my phone with my wife or children to make calls or watch videos. I don’t share it with outsiders.

qa.question: What apps and features do you frequently use?
qa.answer: I mostly use phone calls, WhatsApp, YouTube, and the camera. I use the camera if the supervisor asks for photos of the gate or surroundings. I don’t use many other apps.

qa.question: Do you read app permissions before allowing them?
qa.answer: No, I don’t read them. I cannot understand what is written. If the app doesn’t work, I press ‘Allow’.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app is safe to use?
qa.answer: If my supervisor, friends, or my children say the app is okay, then I use it. I don’t install apps by myself.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted messages, photos, or apps for privacy?
qa.answer: Yes, I delete photos after sending them to my supervisor. I also delete WhatsApp messages when my phone memory becomes full.

qa.question: What do you do before giving your phone for repair?
qa.answer: I remove the SIM card. I don’t know how to delete everything properly, so I feel worried when giving it for repair.

qa.question: Have you asked someone for help with phone problems?
qa.answer: Yes, I ask my children or go to a nearby mobile shop. I feel uncomfortable because they can see my phone, but I need help.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I trust my wife and children. I don’t trust strangers or residents with personal matters.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Yes, I save some contacts with short names so others don’t understand who they are.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: I helped another watchman use WhatsApp calling. I only showed him how to answer calls.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera, microphone, or location?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know how to do that. I didn’t know apps could use those things without opening them.

qa.question: What do you do when you get warning messages on your phone?
qa.answer: I get scared and close the message. I usually show it to my children or ask someone else.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think the app can see those photos and contacts. I don’t know what happens after that.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, because family photos and WhatsApp messages are there. I feel shy and worried.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your photos or apps without asking?
qa.answer: Once, the repair person opened my phone to check storage. I didn’t say anything, but I felt bad.

qa.question: Do you use a lock screen on your phone?
qa.answer: Yes, I use a pattern lock. My wife also knows it.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones?
qa.answer: I don’t know the difference. I use whatever others tell me to use.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand phone settings?
qa.answer: I ask my children or sometimes another watchman who knows phones better.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my children and friends tell me not to share OTPs and not to answer unknown calls. I listen to them.

scenarios.Broken Phone: Before giving my phone for repair, I remove the SIM card. If my children are nearby, I ask them to check the phone first.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If my wife or children use my phone, I don’t worry much. I check messages later.
scenarios.Installing a New App: I don’t install apps myself. I ask my children or friends to install them.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I help them make calls or receive calls. I don’t explain app permissions.
scenarios.Using Someone Else’s Phone: I only make the call I need and return the phone quickly.
scenarios.Giving Away Phone: I ask my children to delete everything before giving it away.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I don’t know about cloud backup. If deleted photos come back, I will be very worried.
scenarios.Free Public WiFi: I don’t use free WiFi. I only use mobile data.
scenarios.Lottery Call: I receive such calls sometimes. I cut the call and block the number.
scenarios.Emergency Bank Transfer: If someone asks for money urgently, I first call them or ask my children before doing anything.
